title: Court dismisses bid to force Johnson to seek Brexit extension
text:
A legal challenge that sought to force Boris Johnson to request an extension was dismissed | Ian Forsyth/Getty Images Court dismisses bid to force Johnson to seek Brexit extension Campaigners say they will appeal the decision.

LONDON — A legal challenge that sought to force Boris Johnson to request an extension to Brexit negotiations if no deal is agreed by October 19 was dismissed Monday.

The Court of Session, Scotland’s highest civil court, rejected the petition brought by businessman Dale Vince, Scottish National Party MP Joanna Cherry and anti-Brexit lawyer Jolyon Maugham.

They wanted a judge to order that Johnson had to send a letter to the EU requesting an extension, and ban him from frustrating the purpose of the Benn Act, which was passed by the U.K. parliament last month in order to stop a no-deal Brexit. The petitioners feared the U.K. government may try to get around the act, for instance, by sending another letter to Brussels effectively cancelling the first one, or by persuading another EU member state to veto the U.K.’s request for an extension.

Judge Lord Pentland dismissed the case. Referring to government documents submitted to the court, which show Johnson accepts he must send a letter to the EU requesting an extension, he said in his ruling: “Having regard to the Prime Minister's and the Government’s unequivocal assurances before the court ... that they will comply with the 2019 Act, I am not persuaded that it is necessary for the court to grant the orders sought or any variant of them.”

He added: “I am not satisfied that the petitioners have made out their case based on reasonable apprehension of breach of statutory duty on the part of the Prime Minister.”

The petitioners said they plan to appeal his decision, with their appeal expected to be heard Tuesday.

Commenting on the ruling, Maugham tweeted: “The question whether this loss matters depends on whether you think I am right or the Court is right. But, on any view, there are now risks of an unlawful Brexit that would not, had the decision gone the other way, have existed.”

In a court hearing Friday, Andrew Webster, the lawyer representing the government, argued that imposing any orders on the prime minister could “ruin” the U.K.’s negotiating strategy with the EU.

Asked about the Scottish court case shortly before the ruling was announced, Johnson said: “We will study any judgments, of course, very closely, as we always do. We will respect the law. And we will leave the European Union on October 31. Clearly that’s what the people of this country voted for. I think most people just want to get Brexit done.”

A panel of judges of the Court of Session’s Inner House will hold a hearing Tuesday on another part of the case: whether the court can use its “nobile officium” power to, in effect, sign a letter to EU leaders requesting an extension to negotiations on behalf of the prime minister.

CORRECTION: This article has been updated to correct the name of the businessman who brought the case to court.
description: Campaigners say they will appeal the decision.
